statement:
Let $(A_n)$ be a sequence of mutually exclusive events whose is the
sample space and let $E$ be any event. All of the events have nonzero
probability ($P(E) > 0$ and $P(A_n) > 0$ for all $n$). Bayes’ Theorem
states

$$P(A_j|E) = \frac{P(A_j)P(E|A_j)}{\sum_i P(A_i)P(E|A_i)}$$

for any $A_j \in (A_n)$.

A simpler formulation is:

$$P(A|B) = \frac{P(B|A)P(A)}{P(B)}$$

For two events, $A$ and $B$ (also with nonzero probability).

Statistics: Principles and Applications for Engineering and the
